Award.AwardTitle: SaTC-EDU: EAGER: Development and Evaluation of Privacy Education Tools via Open Collaboration

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
As the Internet grows in importance, it is vital to develop methods and techniques for educating end-users to improve their awareness of online privacy. However, the development of Web-based education tools for online privacy is still in the early stage. Traditional solutions involving professionals can make the tool development costly. It is also not clear how motivating, inspiring, and/or effective these education tools are to general users, especially novice users who have rarely dealt with privacy issues.

Through interdisciplinary research between a computer scientist and two social scientists, this project aims to exploit both group-sourcing and crowdsourcing approaches to develop effective education tools for online privacy. Research activities include: (1) designing novel methods to generate collective wisdom from non-expert user groups for the development of innovative ideas of privacy education tools; (2) investigating the main characteristics of a wise group that is capable of developing creative and high-quality ideas for privacy training; (3) developing methods to enhance the originality and practicality of the ideas generated by the non-expert groups; and (4) integrating group-sourcing, crowdsourcing, and experts' opinions to evaluate the effectiveness of the developed privacy training tools.

This interdisciplinary, high-risk, high-payoff project will dramatically advance research in security/privacy and social science. The research results will be disseminated broadly through curricular materials appropriate for computer science, College of Arts and Letters, and MBA students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Overview

As the Internet grows in importance, it is vital to develop methods and techniques for training end-users to improve their awareness of online privacy. Web-based education tools have been proven effective in many domains and have been increasingly adopted by many online professional and educational services. However, the development of Web-based education tools for online privacy is still in the early stages. Given the wide use of Internet and the severe impact of privacy accidents, there exists an urgent need for developing privacy training tools that can help to educate end-users to improve their awareness and concerns of online privacy.

Developing effective privacy training and education techniques is challenging. The traditional solutions always involve privacy experts who have sophisticated expertise, deep technical skills, as well as broad experience. However, the involvement of professionals can make the tool development costly. Furthermore, it is not clear how motivating, inspiring, and/or effective these training tools are to general users of varying backgrounds, experience, and expertise of privacy, especially novice users who have rarely dealt with privacy issues.

Intellectual merit

This interdisciplinary research between a computer scientist and a social scientist aims to exploit collective intelligence and crowd wisdom to develop effective training and education tools that can enhance end-users’ understanding of online privacy. The project focuses on the privacy issues of three popular Internet application scenarios: social networking, cloud computing, and mobile computing. The theoretical significance is that the proposal advances the field by addressing four important issues that have not been explored extensively. First, it designs novel methods based on crowd-based generic algorithms to aggregate the ideas of crowds and generate collective wisdom to develop effective privacy education tools. Second, it investigates the main characteristics of a wise crowd that is capable of developing creative and high-quality ideas for privacy training. Third, it develops various methods to enhance the originality and the practicality of the crowd-generated ideas. Fourth, it uses crowds to evaluate the effectiveness of the privacy training tool developed based on the crowd-generated ideas by measuring trainees’ reaction, learning, behavior, and results of using the tool.

Broader impact

This EAGER project has performed interdisciplinary research successfully among computer science and social science. It also has educational impacts involved women and underrepresented students into cybersecurity research. Furthermore, the team improved the prototype of the privacy education game, which is available to the public at http://dmlab.cs.stevens.edu/depet.  Approximately two thousands Internet users have played the game and gave their comments and feedback.
